large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: Happy in Our Skin

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to review the letters Bb, Dd, Jj, and Kk; engage children with a song; and introduce vocabulary (splendid).
Begin Story Time by asking, What does our skin do?
Read for enjoyment and understanding.
Check understanding, Differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information to describe.
Produce at least 20 letter-sound correspondences; Write uppercase and lowercase letters.
Produce rhyming words.
Identify connections and differences between feelings and behavior.
Sustain attention while listening.
Use possessive pronouns and subject-verb agreement; Try to use new words and grammar.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children recognize and produce words with the beginning sounds of Bb, Dd, Jj, and Kk.
Guide children to match letters and say their sounds.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What are the parts of our bodies? What do they do?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you see someone in your book who is happy in her skin?
Act like a baby! How can you show that you are unhappy? How can you show that you are happy?
What would you use to measure how long your arm is?
Write about something you liked to do when you were a baby.
Draw a picture of some happy babies.
Use crayons, markers, or letter stamps to write the letters Bb, Dd, Jj, and Kk.
What can you build that a baby can play in?

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: Happy in Our Skin

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share Mind Builder understanding feelings and actions and introduce vocabulary (one of a kind).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to Happy in Our Skin.
Read closely and notice when children are showing their feelings through their actions.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information to describe.
Produce at least 20 letter-sound correspondences.
Produce rhyming words.
Identify connections and differences between feelings and behavior.
Identify their own bodies within surroundings and respect others’ personal space.
Use different art materials for exploration and for sensory experience.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Social Studies: People, Past and Present

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Recall with children the Mind Builder.
Invite children to create two drawings, one drawing to show himself or herself as a happy baby and one to show himself or herself as a happy preK child.
Talk about the differences.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What are the parts of our bodies? What do they do?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Do you see children in a book that are very young?
Show how you would help someone who fell on the playground.
Draw five happy faces. Write the number. Show the number with counters.
Write a note to someone you like to hug.
Can you make a picture of someone you like to hug?
Can you see something in the room that starts with the letter Dd? Can you write the word?
Can you show a place where children can play happily?

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: Happy in Our Skin

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Social Studies: People, Past and Present

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build social studies background, engage children in a game of “I Spy,” and introduce vocabulary (terrific, clever)
Begin Story Time by revisiting Happy in Our Skin and asking the guided question, What is special about our skin?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information to describe.
Contribute ideas and participate in group writing.
Identify connections and differences between feelings and behavior.
Identify unique characteristics in themselves, classmates, and children from other cultures.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the parts of different plants and animals.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Social Studies: People, Past and Present

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Encourage children to use connecting cubes to make something “clever.”
Talk about what makes things alike (same colors, same patterns, same shapes) or different (different colors, different patterns, different shapes).
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What are the parts of our bodies? What do they do?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Does a child in the book remind you of someone you know?
Act out how it feels when your skin is tickled.
What does our skin do after we get a cut or scrape?
Can you write a word that rhymes with toes?
Draw a picture of your face. What color are your eyes?
Can you write or draw animals whose names start with B?
Can you make a b with blocks? How can you change the b into a d?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Happy in Our Skin by Fran Manushkin, illustrated by Lauren Tobia. Text copyright © 2015 by Fran Manushkin. Illustrations copyright © 2015 by Lauren Tobia. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Candlewick Press.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Chart of Big Ideas: Head, Shoulders, Knees, and Toes

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about our sense of touch, listen for rhyming words, and introduce vocabulary (kneesand shoulders).
Begin Story Time by connecting Head, Shoulders, Knees, and Toes, and Happy in Our Skin.
Read closely to answer this week’s concept question: What are the parts of our bodies? What do they do?
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information to describe.
Produce rhyming words.
Write for different purposes.
Identify own body within surroundings and respects others’ personal space.
Manage emotions as needed (Self-Regulation).
Use possessive pronouns and subject-verb agreement; Try to use new words and grammar.
Sustain attention while listening.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the parts of different plants and animals.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Play Simon Says.
Have children follow along as you lead them to move body parts while playing Simon Says.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What are the parts of our bodies? What do they do?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: On what part of the body are the eyes, ears, mouth, and nose?
With a friend, pretend you are frogs and jump! Compare who can jump farther. Who can jump higher?
Can you count your toes (on both feet)?
Think about when you were a baby. Describe what parts of your body you used to get around.
Can you trace your hand? Compare your hand with your friend’s hand. Whose hand is bigger?
Can you name things you can do with your body that start with the letters B, D, K, and J? (i.e., bounce/bend; dance/dive; kick/kneel; jump/jog)
Can you make something that bends like your knee? What did you use to make it?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Happy in Our Skin by Fran Manushkin, illustrated by Lauren Tobia. Text copyright © 2015 by Fran Manushkin. Illustrations copyright © 2015 by Lauren Tobia. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Candlewick Press.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: Happy in Our Skin

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to engage children actively and revisit vocabulary (terrific, one of a kind).
Begin Story Time by asking, How can we move in the skin we’re in?
Read and retell interactively for engagement.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Share and repeat the details in a text.
Write for different purposes.
Identify connections and differences between feelings and behavior.
Identify unique characteristics in themselves, classmates, and children from other cultures.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the parts of different plants and animals.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: How does our skin help us?
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What are the parts of our bodies? What do they do?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What does your skin keep in? What does it keep out?
Can you perform a dance that uses all of your body parts?
Can you make a print of your pointer finger? Did you know that your fingerprint is one of a kind?
What terrific thing can you do with your body? Write about it.
Imagine something that is very soft to touch. Can you create a picture of it?
Write the uppercase letters B, D, J, and K. Now write those letters in lowercase.
On pages 22–23, everyone is at a block party. Pretend your classroom is having a block party! Can you work together as a group to build something for the party?

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Produce at least 20 distinct letter sound correspondences in the language of instruction.
Begin to understand difference and connection between emotions/ feelings and behaviors.
Are aware of where own bodies are in space and respect personal boundaries.
Use regular and irregular plurals, regular past tense, personal and possessive pronouns and subject-verb agreement.
Attempt to use new vocabulary and grammar in speech.
Uses information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Produce at least 20 distinct letter sound correspondences in the language of instruction.
Begin to understand difference and connection between emotions/feelings and behaviors.
Are aware of where own bodies are in space and respect personal boundaries.
Use a variety of art materials and activities for sensory experience and exploration.
Uses information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Discuss and contribute ideas for drafts composed in whole- /small-group writing activities.
Begin to understand difference and connection between emotions/ feelings and behaviors.
Are aware of where own bodies are in space and respect personal boundaries.
Identify similarities and differences between himself, classmates, and other children inclusive of specific characteristics and cultural influences.
Observe and discuss characteristics of organisms.
Uses information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Independently write to communicate ideas for a variety of purposes.
Are aware of where own bodies are in space and respect personal boundaries.
Able to increase or decrease intensity of emotions more consistently, although adult guidance is sometimes necessary.
Use regular and irregular plurals, regular past tense, personal and possessive pronouns, and subject-verb agreement.
Attempt to use new vocabulary and grammar in speech.
Observe and discuss characteristics of organisms.
Retell or reenact a story after it is read aloud.
Independently write to communicate ideas for a variety of purposes.
Begin to understand difference and connection between emotions/feelings and behaviors.
Identify similarities and differences between himself, classmates, and other children inclusive of specific characteristics and cultural influences.
Observe and discuss characteristics of organisms.
Create or recreate stories, moods, or experiences through dramatic expressions.
